title: CSS Flexbox
summary: Build on your CSS knowledge by diving into Flexbox, a one-dimensional layout technique for helping organize items within your webpage.

atoms.title: Introducing Flexbox Heading
atoms.text: # Introducing Flexbox

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 01 Introducing Flexbox
Introducing Flexbox Recap
atoms.text: To use flexbox set the `display` property of a div to `flex`. The items inside that element will automatically become flex items, and you can then use the flexbox syntax in your CSS code.

atoms.title: A Quick Flexbox Example Heading
atoms.text: # A Quick Flexbox Example

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 02 Introducing Flexbox Example
Introducing Flexbox Example Summary
atoms.text: By setting an element's `display` property to `flex`, all elements inside of it become flex items that can be laid out in a customized way following design patterns like columns, rows, alignment, and distribution.

atoms.title: Introducing Flexbox Quiz

question.prompt: What do you add to your code to begin using flexbox properties?

answers.text: By setting the `display` property of the parent element to `flex`.
answers.incorrect_feedback: The parent element’s `display` property should be set to `flex`.

answers.text: By setting the `display` properties of the items inside the parent container to `flex`.
answers.incorrect_feedback: The parent element is set to `flex` and the children items are automatically turned into flex items.

answers.text: Just start using flexbox properties like `align-items` and `justify-content`.
answers.incorrect_feedback: In order to use flexbox properties you must set the `display` to  `flex.`

atoms.title: Introducing Flexbox Summary
Introducing Flexbox Further Research
atoms.text:
### Further research

For more information about a Flexbox overview, see [this MDN entry](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/CSS_layout/Flexbox).

atoms.title: Axes and Direction with Flexbox Heading
atoms.text: # Axes and Direction with Flexbox

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 03 Axes And Direction With Flexbox
Axes and Direction with Flexbox Recap
atoms.text:
The Flexbox model relies on two axes: the main axis and the cross axis. The main axis is defined by flex-direction, which has four possible values:

- `row`
- `row-reverse`
- `column`
- `column-reverse`

The two row settings will create the main axis horizontally - or `inline` direction. The two column settings will create the main axis vertically - or `block` direction. `block` or `inline` here refer to the CSS display settings which we have covered previously. 

The axis determines the flow of your content - you can think of this as being either rows or columns - and they will be determined when you start aligning and justifying content within a flex container.

atoms.title: Axes and Direction with Flexbox Example Prep
atoms.text:
# Axes and Direction in Action

After setting an element's display to flex, the next thing you will usually want to state is whether the elements inside the container should be laid out in rows or columns. You can do this using the `flex-direction` property, and setting its value to either column or row.

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 04 Axes And Direction With Flexbox Example
Axes and Direction with Flexbox Example Summary
Axes and Direction with Flexbox Problem Set

question.prompt: Which of the following are true?
question.default_feedback: In fact, all these things are true!

answers.text: If the `flex-direction` is set to `row` or `row-reverse` the main axis is horizontal.
If the `flex-direction` is set to `column` or `column-reverse` the main axis is vertical.
If the main axis is horizontal the cross axis is vertical.
The two axis control the flow of space in flexbox and correspond to the `align-items` and `justify-content` properties.

atoms.title: Axes and Direction with Flexbox Summary
atoms.text: Axes and direction are important concepts for understanding flexbox. They are both conceptual and technical which can be tricky. One suggestion is to try and draw your flex containers out first in a notebook. This can be helpful for mapping out axes and direction.

atoms.title: Axes and Direction with Flexbox Further Research
atoms.text:
### Further Research

For more on axis and direction with flexbox see the [documentation here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Flexible_Box_Layout/Basic_Concepts_of_Flexbox#The_two_axes_of_flexbox).

atoms.title: Ordering Elements with Flexbox Heading
atoms.text: # Ordering Elements with Flexbox

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 05 Ordering Elements With Flexbox
Ordering Elements with Flexbox Recap
atoms.text:
There are three ways to explicitly set the order in which items will appear in a grid.

1. Moving the HTML code for the elements themselves to reorder
2. Appending `-reverse` to `row` or `column` will reverse the order in the specified row or column
3. Using the `order` property of the individual items inside the grid

atoms.title: Ordering Elements with Flexbox Example Prep
atoms.text:
# Ordering Elements Demo

`flex-direction:row;` will lay elements out from left to right. But `flex-direction:row-reverse` will flip that order and display elements from right to left.

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 06 Ordering Elements With Flexbox V3
Ordering Elements with Flexbox Example Summary
atoms.text: The row and columns settings for flex elements can be reversed by appending `-reverse` to either property value.

atoms.title: Ordering Elements with Flexbox Problem Set

question.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a valid way to order elements inside a grid with Flexbox?
question.default_feedback: Practice makes perfect. Try each of these out yourself to tell which one isn’t valid! Hint: does just the name an element cause anything to happen?

answers.text: Moving the HTML code for the elements themselves to reorder
Appending `-reverse` to `row` or `column` to reverse the order in the specified row or column
Naming the elements in numeric order
Using the `order` property of the individual items inside the grid

atoms.title: Ordering Elements with Flexbox Summary
atoms.text:
### Summary

The order of flex items is by default determined by the order they appear in your code. You can explicitly change this order using either `-reverse` or with the CSS property `order`.

atoms.title: Ordering Elements with Flexbox Further Research
atoms.text:
### Further Research

For more information on ordering flex items, you can see this section of [the flexbox MDN article](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/CSS_layout/Flexbox#Ordering_flex_items).

concepts.title: Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox

atoms.title: Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox Heading
atoms.text: # Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 07 Aligning Items   Justifying Content With Flexbox
Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox Recap
atoms.text:
To align items on the cross axis use `align-items` with the possible values:
- stretch
- flex-start
- flex-end
- center

To justify content on the main axis use `justify-content`, which has the possible values:
- flex-start
- flex-end
- center
- space-around
- space-between
- space-evenly

atoms.title: Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox Example Prep
atoms.text:
# Aligning & Justifying in Action

Aligning, justifying, and distributing is what flexbox is all about. Up next, we will focus in on two of the most powerful properties that flex introduces to achieve such easy and elegant layouts.

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 08 Aligning Items   Justifying Content With Flexbox Example
Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox Example Summary
atoms.text: By setting different values for the properties `align-items` and `justify-content` you can easily create elegant distribution of elements across the available space.

atoms.title: Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox Quiz

question.prompt: Which of the following is true?

answers.text: The align-items property will align the items on the cross axis.
answers.incorrect_feedback: Nailed it! And this one was tricky! Great job!

answers.text: The justify-content property will align the items on the cross axis.
The align-items property will align the items on the main axis.

atoms.title: Aligning Items & Justifying Content with Flexbox Further Research
atoms.text:
### Further Research

For further research on the topics covered in this section, see this MDN article [Alignment, justification and distribution of free space between items](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Flexible_Box_Layout/Basic_Concepts_of_Flexbox#Alignment_justification_and_distribution_of_free_space_between_items).

Reading the documentation will make you smarter and enjoy coding more!

atoms.title: ND001 C01 L03 09 Recap
